results.title: John Keats: poet
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and John Barnes
results.brief_description: Written by Archibald MacLeish, this film dramatizes the life of Keats from his early years in England until his death in Rome at the age of 26. Relating the tragedies in his personal life to his development as a poet, the film portrays Keat’s reactions to deaths in his family, financial worries, brutal criticism to his poetry, a troubled love affair, and the failing health that Keats endured, and rose above in his exceeding devotion to his art. Excerpts from his letters and poetry reveal the integrity of the man and the genius of the poet. Narrated by James Mason.

results.title: John Huston's Dublin
results.creator_credit: Learning Corporation of America, John McGreevy and Pat Ferns
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Cities”.
A leisurely stroll through Dublin with John Huston, examining the uprising of 1916 through the plight of Ireland today.

results.title: John Huston
results.creator_credit: BBC Film Unit and Hugh Burnett
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face to Face”.
John Freeman interviews the distinguished American film director John Huston. Originally signed as a writer for Warner Brothers in 1938, his career was interrupted by the war. In 1948 he won the New York Film Critics Award for the Best Direction with “Treasure of Sierra Madre” which simultaneously earned his father Walter Huston an Oscar. His other films include “The Asphalt Jungle” “Moulin Rouge”, “Moby Dick” and “The Misfits”. In this probing interview, John Huston responds to questions related to censorship, the responsibility of the director and his reasons for selecting to work in this medium. He also frankly discusses his childhood, his marriages and his hopes.

results.title: John Grierson
results.brief_description: John Grierson’s address on the occasion of the “Thirty Years of the British Documentary” season at the National Film Theatre, London, in August 1959. He outlines the basic intentions of the early documentary filmmakers and the influence which British documentary has since had on the rest of the world.

results.title: John Gilpin
results.creator_credit: BFI, Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films, John Halas, Joan Maude and Michael Warne
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Painter and poet: an experiment in words, music and paintings”.
The fourth and final part of a series devised by Joan Maude and Michael Warre incorporating the works of writers, painters and musicians to create an experimental animated film. This part consists of one short film. ‘John Gilpin’ by William Cowper, narrated by Cecil Trouncer, drawings by Ronald Searle (9:00 mins). Photography by W. Traylor and R. Turk, music by Matyas Seiber, edited by Jack King.

results.title: John Forrest: Clydeside computer
results.creator_credit: London Television Service and Central Office of Information
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Pattern of People”.
John Forrest is a marine engineer leading a team of designers and engineers using a complex hybrid computer in one of the Glasgow shipyards. The film shows Forrest’s team at work on board ship, in the yards and, in an entirely different field, building a mathematical model of the blood’s chemical processes for the purposes of medical research.

results.title: John Dowie: sculptor
results.creator_credit: Film Partnership (Vic.), Alcoa Australia and Graham Bye
results.brief_description: Narrated by the sculptor, the film shows a number of works by John Dowie. The Adelaide-born sculptor uses plaster, stone, bronze and aluminium as mediums for his works. Various sculptures around Adelaide are featured; the wall reliefs in the Library of the South Australian Institute of Technology and the fountain at Victoria Square amongst them.

results.title: John Corbett: textile teacher
results.creator_credit: Victorian Film Corporation, Australia Council, Nina Syme and Terry McMahon
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”.
John Corbett works at the Preston Institute, taking classes in weaving, tapestry, lace-making and other fibre work. He is a very enthusiastic teacher, although he has had no formal training he likes to bombard his students with new ideas from different people and cultures.
